The Centre Pompidou in Paris, France, announced today that it intends to reopen by the end of 2020 after an extensive renovation project that began in October. The modernized museum will boast of an exhibition pavilion that will better display the works of the Centre Pompidou’s collection and will be equipped with a more modern and intimate space for educational and cultural activities. The renovation project also includes the installation of new works by contemporary artists, including Mark di Suvero and Mihai Focock, and the restoration of the building’s original facade and interior.The renovation of the Pompidou was completed in conjunction with the renovation of the Centre Pompidou. The renovation project, which began in 2016, involved the use of more than 4,500 materials and took seven years to complete, including the recovery of the building’s original foundations. The Centre Pompidou will be inaugurated as the new building of the Centre Pompidou, which will be inaugurated during a public celebration on August 9.
